ClsC_b2adc080.class_description: Biological and ecological processes related to plant reproduction outcomes, including the generation of fruits and seeds and their dispersal in the environment.
ClsC_b2adc080.evidence_excerpt: Birds facilitate plant reproduction, contributing to the production of fruits and seeds and their spread for colonization.

members.entity_description: Ecological process in which seeds are transported away from parent plants, often by birds consuming fruits and excreting seeds elsewhere, aiding plant reproduction, colonization, and spatial distribution.
members.resolution_context: All three refer to the same ecological process of birds spreading seeds for plant reproduction and distribution, differing only in wording and context.

members.entity_description: Generation of fruits and seeds by plants as an outcome of successful pollination and reproduction.
members.resolution_context: By feeding on nectar and transferring pollen from flower to flower, these birds facilitate the reproduction of plants and contribute to the production of fruits and seeds.

ClsC_bb95200d.class_description: Ecosystem services that are provided or strongly supported by bird activity, including both general ecosystem benefits and specific bird-mediated functions.
ClsC_bb95200d.evidence_excerpt: Benefits humans receive from ecosystems, supported by healthy bird populations ... natural pest control by birds.

members.entity_description: Benefits humans receive from ecosystems, supported by healthy bird populations and habitats.
members.resolution_context: Protecting bird populations and their habitats is crucial for maintaining biodiversity, supporting ecosystem services, and ensuring the health and resilience of ecosystems for future generations.

members.entity_description: Ecosystem service in which birds biologically control pest species by feeding on them, reducing pest populations and contributing to ecosystem stability.
members.resolution_context: All three mentions describe the same bird-mediated reduction of pest populations as a beneficial ecological role, differing only in phrasing and granularity, so they should be represented as a single ecosystem service entity.

ClsC_dcd90b8e.class_description: Biotic components representing birds collectively and their populations in ecosystems, used to assess and support biodiversity and ecosystem health.
ClsC_dcd90b8e.evidence_excerpt: Bird species collectively ... bird populations in a given area, monitored and protected.

members.entity_description: Populations of birds in a given area, whose numbers and demographic structure are monitored and protected to assess and support ecosystem health, biodiversity, and ecosystem services.
members.resolution_context: Both mentions refer to the same general concept of bird populations in ecosystems, differing only in contextual emphasis (monitoring vs. protection).

members.entity_description: Bird species collectively, a group of animals that play multiple ecological roles in ecosystems worldwide, including seed dispersal, natural pest control, pollination, nutrient cycling, and environmental monitoring.
members.resolution_context: All mentions refer to birds collectively as a group of species playing similar ecological roles (seed dispersal, pest control, etc.) in the same context, differing only in wording and granularity.

ClsC_0066a686.class_description: Ecological processes involving changes in pest populations, including rapid damaging outbreaks and their biological control by birds.
ClsC_0066a686.evidence_excerpt: Outbreaks of pests that can damage crops ... reduction of pest populations by birds.

members.entity_description: Rapid increases in pest numbers that can damage crops and vegetation.
members.resolution_context: By preying on insects, birds help prevent outbreaks of pests that can damage crops and other vegetation.

members.entity_description: Ecosystem service in which birds biologically control pest species by feeding on them, reducing pest populations and contributing to ecosystem stability.
members.resolution_context: All three mentions describe the same bird-mediated reduction of pest populations as a beneficial ecological role, differing only in phrasing and granularity, so they should be represented as a single ecosystem service entity.
